title: Cladistic analysis and taxonomic revision of the subfamily Leiosteninae Šilhavý, 1973 (Arachnida, Opiliones, Agoristenidae)
authors: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro.
abstract: A. anitas, A. matintaperera and A. soaresorum são transferidas para Otrera gen. nov.; A. albimaculata, A. bicoloripes and A. glabrata são transferidas para Pantariste gen. nov.; A. quadrata, A. flavomaculata, A. granulosa and A. subparamera são transferidas para Soroche gen. nov., junto com S. butulu sp. nov. Para os demais gêneros, duas novidades são propostas: Nemastygnus guache sp. nov. é descrita como a segunda espécie de Nemastygnus e Vimina é sinonimizada com Barinas, resultando em Barinas virginis comb. nov. sentences: ABSTRACT
CLADISTIC ANALYSIS AND TAXONOMIC REVISION OF THE SUBFAMILY LEIOSTENINAE ŠILHAVÝ, 1973 (ARACHNIDA, OPILIONES, AGORISTENIDAE)
Andrés Felipe García Rincón Advisor: Adriano Brilhante Kury

Leiosteninae is the most diverse subfamily into Agoristenidae, with 12 genera and 59 species found mainly i n Northern South America, Amazon and the Andes range . However, their internal relationships remain unexplored. In the present work, the monophyly of Leiosteninae is tested by means of a cladistic analysis under maximum parsimony using a matrix with 72 terminals and 119 morphological characters. A ll type species of the genera, 58 of the 59 species of the subfamily and four new species were scored. The results support the creation of Rivetininae subfam. nov. to allocate Rivetinus . Leiosteninae is corroborated as a monophyletic group, with the transf erence of the genera Andrescava and Sabanilla to Globibuninae. Andrescava is considered a junior subjective synonym of Globibunus; Avima olmosa is transferred to Globibunus, resulting in Globibunus olmosus comb. nov. ; Avima scabra and Avima octomaculata are considered Globibuninae incertae sedis . Into Leiosteninae, the type species of Avima is redescribed and the genus is redefined, now containing four species: A. leiobuniformis , A. intermedia , A. venezuelica and A. leucobunus . The remaining species of Avim a are reallocated to previous or newly described genera, as follows (new combinations are not shown): A. naranjoi is considered as a Leiosteninae incertae sedis ; Avima bubonica is transferred to Barlovento ; Avima plana , A. quirozi and A. vigirima are trans ferred to Paravima; A. azulitai , A. bordoni , A. checkeleyi , A. chapmani , A. falconensis and A. troglobia are transferred to Balrog gen. nov.; A. tuttifrutti is transferred to Eyabida gen. nov. ; A. chiguaraensis is transferred to Jaibana gen. nov. , together to Jaibana wayuu sp. nov. ; A. palpogranulosa and A. severa are transferred to Lionza gen. nov. ; Tegua u -viride gen. et sp. nov. ; A. anitas, A. matintaperera and A. soaresorum are transferred to Otrera gen. nov. ; A. albimaculata , A. bicoloripes and A. glabrata are transferred to Pantariste gen. nov. ; A. quadrata , A. flavomaculata , A. granulosa and A. subparamera are transferred to Soroche gen. nov. , together with S. butulu sp. nov. For the remaining genera, two novelties are proposed: ix

Nemastygnus guache sp. nov. is described as the second species of Nemastygnus and Vimina is synonymized with Barinas , resulting in Barinas virginis comb. nov. Avima , Leptostygnus , Muscopilio gen. nov. (in press), Ocoita , Taulisa and Vima are maintained into Leiosteninae. Finally, taxonomical keys for the subfamilies of Agoristenidae and the genera of Leiosteninae are provided, as well as distribution maps.
Key-words: Harvestmen, Phylogeny, South America, Systematics.
Rio de Janeiro February 2021

RESUMO
REVISÃO TAXONÔMICA E ANÁLISE CLADÍSTICA DA SUBFAMÍLIA LEIOSTENINAE ŠILHAVÝ, 1973 (ARACHNIDA, OPILIONES, AGORISTENIDAE)
Andrés Felipe García Rincón Orientador: Adriano Brilhante Kury

Leiosteninae é a subfamília mais diversa de Agoristenidae, com 12 gêneros e 59 espécies, encontrados principalmente no norte da América do Sul, Amazônia e na cordilheira dos Andes. Não entanto, suas relações internas permanecem pouco exploradas. No presente trabalho o monofiletismo de L eiosteninae é testado com uma análise cladística utilizando máxima parcimônia sobre uma matriz com 72 táxons e 119 caracteres morfológicos. Todas as espécies -tipo dos gêneros, 58 das 59 espécies descritas da subfamília e quatro novas espécies foram incluída s. Os resultados suportam a criação de Rivetininae subfam. nov. para alocar Rivetinus . Leiosteninae é confirmada como um grupo monofilético, com a transferência de Andrescava e Sabanilla para Globibuninae. Andrescava é considerado sinônimo júnior subjetivo de Globibunus; Avima olmosa é transferida para Globibunus, resultando em Globibunus olmosus comb. nov. ; Avima scabra e Avima octomaculata são consideradas Globibuninae incertae sedis . Dentro de Leiosteninae, a espéc ie-tipo de Avima é redescrita e o gênero redefinido, agora contendo quatro espécies: A. leiobuniformis , A. intermedia , A. venezuelica e A. leucobunus . O restante das espécies de Avima são realocadas em gêneros já descritos ou novos, assim (as novas combina ções resultantes não são explicitadas): A. naranjoi é considerada Leiosteninae incertae sedis ; Avima bubonica é transferida para Barlovento ; Avima plana , A. quirozi e A. vigirima são transferidas para Paravima; A. azulitai , A. bordoni , A. checkeleyi , A. ch apmani , A. falconensis e A. troglobia são transferidas para Balrog gen. nov. ; A. tuttifrutti é transferida para Eyabida gen. nov. ; A. chiguaraensis é transferida para Jaibana gen. nov. , junto com Jaibana wayuu sp. nov. ; A. palpogranulosa and A. severa são transferidas para Lionza gen. nov. ; Tegua u -viride gen. et sp. nov. ; A. anitas, A. matintaperera and A. soaresorum são transferidas para Otrera gen. nov. ; A. albimaculata , A. bicoloripes and A. glabrata são transferidas para Pantariste gen. nov. ; A. quadrata , A. flavomaculata , A. granulosa and A. subparamera são transferidas para Soroche gen. nov. , junto com S. butulu sp. nov. Para os xi

demais gêneros, duas novidades são propostas: Nemastygnus guache sp. nov. é descrita como a segunda espécie de Nemastyg nus e Vimina é sinonimizada com Barinas , resultando em Barinas virginis comb. nov. Avima , Leptostygnus , Muscopilio gen. nov. (em prensa), Ocoita , Taulisa e Vima são mantidos dentro de Leiosteninae. Finalmente, chaves taxonômicas para as subfamílias de Agoristenidae e os gêneros de Leiosteninae são apresentadas, assim como mapas de distribuição.
Palavras -chave: Opiliones, filogenia, América do Sul, sistemática.

INTRODUCTION

The harvestmen (Opiliones Sundevall, 1833) constitute the fourth most diverse group of Arachnida (after Araneae, Acariformes and Parasitiformes) ( Beaulieu et al. 2011, Harvey 2002, Zhang 2013 ), with four extant suborders, 65 families, 164 5 genera and 6 637 valid species, being Laniatores Thorell, 1876 the most diverse suborder (3 9 families an d 4189 species) (Kury et al. 2020 ).

The Neotropical laniator family Agoristenidae Šilhavý, 1973 is an uncommon albeit diverse group (26 gen., 77 spp.), divided in three subfamilies: Agoristeninae Šilhavý, 1973 from the Greater Antilles (12 gen., 15 spp. ), Globibuninae Kury, 2012 from Ecuador (2 gen., 3 spp. ) and Leiosteninae Šilhavý, 1973 from northern South America (12 gen., 59 spp.) ( Ahumada et al. 2020 ; García & Pastrana -M., in press ; Kury 2013 ; Villarreal et al., in press ). Leiosteninae are distribut ed mainly in Andes, Amazon and Caribbean regions of Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela (Porto & Colmenares 2014; García & Villarreal 2020: fig. 9).
Historical background of Leiosteninae

The first known representatives of Leiosteninae (i.e. Vima insignis Hirst, 1912 and Sabanilla ornata Roewer, 1913) were described in Phalangodidae Tricommatinae and Gonyleptidae Prostygninae , respectively (Kury 1997). In the 1940s, several genera that today are Agoristenidae were initially described as Tricommatinae. However, a long time after the first families of Laniatores were proposed, Šilhavý (1973) described the family Agoristenidae with two subfamilies: Agoristeninae (type genus Agoristenus Šilhavý, 1973 from Cuba) and Leiosteninae (type genus Leiostenus Šilhavý, 1973 from Trinidad).

Shortly afterwards, Šilhavý (1979) firstly reported the Leiosteninae from Venezuela, with a new subspeci es of Leiostenus leiobuniformis Šilhavý, 1973 and also transferred to Leiosteninae Phalangozea , anachronistically described shortly before as a Phalangodidae (Muñoz -Cuevas 1976).

In the decade of 1980, Soares & Avram (1981) described new species from Vene zuela and recognized Avima Roewer, 1949 , Trinella Goodnight & Goodnight 1947 and Vimula Roewer, 1949 as agoristenids , while González -Sponga (1987) recorded Agoristenidae for northern South America, reviewed the Venezuelan diversity (describing new genera a nd species), and synonymized Trinella , Avima , Leiostenus and Vimula with Vima Hirst, 1912. Additionally, described a third subfamily, Angelininae.

Posteriorly, Kury (1993) corrected the name Angelininae to Angelinae and transferred Leptostygnus Mello -Leitão, 1940 and Sabanilla Roewer, 1913 from Gonyleptidae (Prostygninae) to Agoristenidae (Angelinae) and Agoristenidae (Leiosteninae), respectively. Besides that, he suggested that Vima insignis must be allocated in Angelinae and advanced a close relationship between Angela González - Sponga, 1987 and Leptostygnus .

Pinto -da-Rocha (1996) redefined the concept of the genus Vima , restricting it to include only Vima insignis , and revalidated Trinella to contain the remaining species to the genus, resulting in nume rous new combinations. Additionally, he described three new species of Trinella .

Later, Kury (1997) performed the first phylogenetic analysis of the Agoristenidae, using a matrix of 23 terminals for 31 morphological characters. For the first time the subfamilies of Agoristenidae were tested for monophyly, including a new subfamily, the Zamorinae. In that analysis, Kury retrieved the structure: Zamorinae (Leiosteninae, Agoristeninae) , and detected that Angela was a synonym of Leptostygnus . For that reason, Kury synonymized both subfamilies, and noted that Angelinae González -Sponga, 1987 was a junior homonym of Angelinae Giglio -Tos, 1927 (Mantodea). Finally, he confirmed that Barinas González -Sponga, 1987, Barlovento González -Sponga, 1987, Leptostygnus , Ocoita González -Sponga, 1987, Paravima Caporiacco, 1951, Sabanilla , Trinella, Vima and Vimina González -Sponga, 1987 should be included in Leiosteninae.
One year later, González -Sponga (1998) described four new species of Vima from the Venezu elan Orinoco region.

Kury (2003) transferred Andrescava Roewer, 1957 from Tricommatinae to Leiosteninae and the species Vima albimaculata González -Sponga, 1998 to Trinella, resulting in Trinella albimaculata (González -Sponga, 1998). Besides that, added and corrected localities and cataloged all the information of the subfamily until that moment: 10 genera and 54 species.

Villarreal -M. & Rodríguez -Manzanilla (2003) described Trinella vigirima from the North o f Venezuela and, two years later, Paravima acanthoconus Villarreal -Manzanilla & DoNascimiento (2005) was described from the mountains of Northwestern Venezuela. After that, Villarreal -Manzanilla & Kury (2009) detected that the genus Trinella revalidated by Pinto da Rocha (1996), was an junior homonym of Trinella Bory de Saint Vincent, 1827 (Protista: Ciliophora). Then, they decided to transfer all the species to Avima , the next available junior synonym.

Pinto -da-Rocha & Hara (2009) proposed a revised cla distic analysis using the matrix of Kury (1997), improving some of the coding, and adding ten characters and eight taxa (including nine species and eight genera of Leiosteninae). Their analysis retrieved the same basic topology as that of Kury (1997), with two major clades: one clade with the genus Leptostygnus and another unresolved clade with the remaining genera of Leiosteninae.

Kury (2012) transferred Zamorinae to Cranaidae Roewer, 1913 and created the subfamily Globibuninae (with species from Ecuador ), including it in Agoristenidae. In the same year, Pinto da Rocha et al. (2012) transferred Nemastygnus Roewer, 1929 and Taulisa Roewer, 1956 from Gonyleptidae Metasarcinae to Leiosteninae.
Porto & Colmenares (2014) described a new species of Avima for the Brazilian Amazon and noted the difficulties to compare it with other species, especially those described by González –Sponga.

Six years later , some genera revisions and descriptions of new species were developed. García & Villarreal (2020) revisit ed the genus Leptostygnus, including the description of a new Colombian species, and made notes about the genital morphology in

Leiosteninae. Some months after, García & Kury (2020) reviewed the monotypic genus Vima , designating a lectotype and giving a co mplementary description of Vima insignis , and described a new Colombian species. And, at the end of the same year , Ahumada et al. (2020 ) reviewed the monotypic genus Barinas , described a new species from the Colombian Caribbean, and gave a n emended diagnos is for the genus.

Finally, García & Pastrana ( in press ) described a new species of Avima , being the first record of a n harvestmen from Cordoba depar tment, in northwestern Colombia, and Villarreal et al . (in press), synonymized Avima nigromaculata (González -Sponga, 1998) with Avima quadrata (González -Sponga, 1998), and Ocoita servae González -Sponga, 1987 with Ocoita tapipensis González -Sponga, 1987 .

Thereby, the current conformation of the Leiosteninae (12 gen., 59 spp.) is as follows: Andrescava Roewer, 1957 (2 spp.), Avima Roewer, 1949 (3 4 spp.), Barinas González –Sponga, 1987 ( 2 spp.), Barlovento González –Sponga, 1987 ( 4 spp.), Leptostygnus (3 spp.), Nemastygnus Roewer, 1929 (1 sp.), Ocoita González -Sponga, 1987 (2 spp.), Paravima Caporiacco, 19 51 (6 spp.), Sabanilla Roewer, 1913 (1 sp.), Taulisa Roewer, 1956 (1 sp.), Vima (2 spp.) and Vimina González –Sponga, 1987 (1 sp.).

MATERIALS AND METHODS Nomenclatural acts This thesis must not be considered as a publication in the sense of the article 9 of the ICZN, therefore, any nomenclatural acts herein proposed are considered void for the principles of priority and homonymy. Likewise, information from papers strictly derived from this dissertation is referred to as new information, regardless its release in press. Imaging and mapping Individuals of the species were photographed using the cameras Nikon 5200 and Sony Cybershot DSC -V1 attached to the stereomicroscope, and the multiple images of each species at different focal planes were combined with Combine ZP Suite software (Hadley 2015) to increase the depth of field. The new species were photographed with a Leica M205C stereoscope attached to a Leica DFC450 digital cam era and combined with Leica Application Suite (LAS) software version 4.6.2 . All resultant photographs were posteriorly edited in Photoshop CC 2014 software.

The male genitalia by SEM was dehydrated with Critical Point Drying (CPD), sputter coated with go ld-palladium and examined with a JEOL JSM -6390LV Scanning Electron Microscope of Rudolf Barth Electron Microscopy Platform at the Oswaldo Cruz Institute/Fiocruz and at the Center for Scanning Electron Microscopy of MNRJ . Drawings of the species were made using a stereomicroscope with camera lucida , and digitalized with Inkscape 0.91 software. Color descriptions use the standard names of the 267 Color Centroids of the NBS/IBCC Color System (Jaffer 2001). The distribution maps were made with Quantum GIS 2.1 8.19 software (QGIS team 2018). When listing the examined material, the first order administrative divisions are written in small caps . Geographic coordinates have been transcribed verbatim from the labels and may be in different formats. When no original indications of coordinates were available, those were estimated using Google Maps and Geonames and placed between square brackets.

Terminology The morphological terminology for dorsal scutum follows Kury and Medrano (2016), with modifications : the three examples for Epsilon type shape in Agoristenidae (Agoristenus , Avima and Globibunus ), are used as subdivisions: that for Agoristenus is here called Epsilon type 3 (ovoid, anterior border narrower than posterior border and mid - bulge); that for Avima is here called Epsilon type 2 (subrectangular, anterior and posterior borders slightly narrower than mid -bulge); that for Globibunus is here called Epsilon type 1 (subrectangular, anterior and posterior borders narrower than mid -bulge, marked posterior corners). Additionally, a new subdivision is proposed here, called Epsilon type 4 (subrectangular, with mid bulge and constrictions attenuated), for the new genus Muscopilio gen. nov. (Villarreal & García, in press ). Penis chaetotaxy and nomenclature follows Kury (2 014) and Kury and Villarreal (2015).

Morphome tric abbreviations are: AHF = armature height formula, AL = Abdomen length, AW = Abdomen width, BaCh = basichelicerite, CL = Carapace length, CW = Carapace width, DP = dorsal process, DS = do rsal scutum , DSL = Dorsal scutum length, Fe = F emur, G-S = González -Sponga , LP = L amina p arva, MS = M acrosetae of penis , Pa = Patella, PeL = Pedipalp length, St = S tylus, Ta = T arsus, Ti = Tibia, Tr = T rochanter . All measurements are in mm unless otherwise noted.

Species of which no photographs or fresh material were examined are not (re)described in the results. The genera Vima , Leptostygnus and Barinas were revised under current standards by García & Kury (20 20), Villarreal & García (2020) and Ahumada et al. (2020) (see Appendices III-V).

Taxon sampling The outgroup is r epresented by nine species, being six from the other subfamilies of Leiosteninae: from Agoristeninae, Agoristenus cubanus Šilhavý, 1973 , Ahotta hispaniolica Šilhavý, 1973, and Yunquenus portoricanus Šilhavý, 1973; from Globibuninae, Globibunus rubrofemoratus Roewer, 1912 , Rivetinus minutus Roewer, 1914 and Rivetinus vulcanus (Kury, 1997) . The remaining three species are representatives from other families: Taquara bicoloripes (H. Soares, 1974) (Crypt ogeobiidae), Gerdesius paruensis (H. Soares, 1970) (Gerdesiidae) and Stygnus luteus (Mello -Leitão, 1931) (Stygnidae). The in group is represented by 58 of the 59 described species of Leiosteninae , encompassing representatives of all 12 genera of the subfam ily and including the type
species of all genera, and five new species ( Muscopilio onod sp. nov. , Gen A u-viride sp. nov., Gen B butulu sp. nov. , Gen C wayuu sp. nov. and Nemastygnus guache sp. nov. ) (Table 1).

Settings of parsimony analysis Some characters were taken and modified from Kury (1997), Pinto -da-Rocha & Hara (2009), Kury (2014 ), Kury & Villarreal (2015) and Villarreal & Garc ía (in press ). All characters were (re)written following the proposal of Sereno (2007) and are provided in

Table 2. The character states have been tabulated in a matrix using Mesquite version 3.61 (Maddison & Maddison 2018). Multistate characters were treated as unordered (non - additive). The matrix contains 8568 scorings, 72 taxa and 119 characters ( 75 from exomorphology and 44 from male genital ia) (Table 3).

The analysis was performed in TNT version 1.5 (Goloboff & Catalano, 2016) with heuristic searches for the most parsimonious trees, using parsimony under implied weights (IW), where characters with less homoplasy have more weight (Goloboff, 1993; Goloboff et al., 2008), and with traditional search algorithm and TBR branch swapp ing. Space was allocated for 10 000 trees in memory, 2000 replicates and 500 trees saved per replication. Branch support was calculated using the relative Bremer support or decay index (Bremer, 1994) and bootstrap (Felsenstein, 1985) using 1000 replicates. Characters were optimized with ACCTRAN in Winclada. Character mapping were done in WinClada (Nixon, 2002). The IW method has a K -value that determines how strongly the analyses will weight against homoplasy (Goloboff, 1993). To choose the value of K for this analysis, I used the script for TNT developed by Mirande (2009), whose proposal divides a t regular intervals the mean fit values of each character in the most parsimonious trees obtained under different values of K, and that uses the tree stability as the main criterion for choosing among the obtained trees (Mirande, 2009) (Appendix I) . The mo st stable trees were chosen with the SPR distance (Goloboff et al., 2008), using 2000 replicates (Appendix I I).

RESULTS In the parsimony analyses with implied weighting (IW), 11 intervals with different values of K were used , each one with a single tree (Appendix I) . The best K range for the data matrix was chosen with the highest value of t he similarity coefficient (SPR), in this case, the interval five (K = 5.011) (Appendix I -II). The chosen tree ( 496 steps , CI = 0.3150, RI = 0.6810) corroborated the monophyly of Leiosteninae, if considering three species of Avima (A. scabra (Roewer, 1963), A. octomaculata (Roewer, 1963) and A. olmosa Roewer, 1956) and the genera Sabanilla and Andrescava into Globibuninae (Fig. The genera Leptostygnus , Barinas , Barlovento , Vima , Ocoita , Paravima , Nemastygnus were recovered as monophyletic , while Avima , the most speciose genus of Leiosteninae, resulted as poly phyletic , having species in Globibuninae and in different known and new genera into Leiosteninae. Four new species and eight new genera are described.

Globibuninae
RIVETININAE NEW SUB FAMIL Y

Included genera : Rivetinus Roewer, 1914 Diagnosis . Very small animals (DS + Leg IV length = less than 15 mm). DS Zeta (R. minutus ) or Eta (R. vulcanus ) type. Prosoma with same length as opisthosoma . Ocularium close to anterior margin of DS, globose, occupying half of carapace width. Pedipalpal femur and patella without mesodi stal spine and se tiferous tubercles reduced. Femur of same length as DS, granular. MS-D vertically aligned. MS -E2 u niramous. Corners of LP short and dorsally pointing ( R. minutus ) or long and apically pointing ( R. vulcanus ). Stylus straight, without dorsal ornamentation ( R. minutus ) or with rounded dorsal keel ( R. vulcanus ).
Distribution. ECUADOR: CARCHÍ , El Pelado, 4151 m ( R. minutus ); COTOPAXI , northwestern slope of Mount Cotopaxi, 3500 m ( R. vulcanus ) (Fig. 48).

RIVETINUS ROEWER, 1914 Rivetinus Roewer 1914: 131; Roewer 1923: 127; Roewer 1928 : 537; Mello -Leitão 1932: 45; Mello -Leitão 1935: 93; Mello -Leitão 1938: 143; Rambla 1978b: 304; Kury “Ruvetinus” (incorrect subsequent spelling): Mello -Leitão 1926: 330.

Type species. Rivetinus minutus Roewer, 1919, designated by monotypy. Placement. Originall y in Phalangodidae Tricommatinae. Considered as Grassatores incertae sedis by Kury (2003); transferred to Agoristenidae Zamorinae by Pinto -da-Rocha & Hara (2009) and to Agoristenidae Globibuninae by Kury (2012). Etymology.

Included species : Rivetinus minutus Roewer, 1914; Rivetinus vulcanus (Kury, Remarks . According to the present analysis, Rivetinus should be included in a new subfamily in the base of Agoristenidae , Rivetininae subf. nov. (Figs 1, 2). The species of Rivetinus were studied in Pinto-da-Rocha & Hara (2009) and Kury ( 1997, 2012 ) and are not treated here .
GLOBIBUNINAE KURY, 2012
Included genera: Sabanilla Roewer, 1913 New Familial Assignment , Globibunus Roewer, 1912 .

Emended diagnosis . DS Epsilon type 1. DS and ocularium densely covered with granules. Ocularium close to anterior margin of DS, occupying half ( Sabanilla ) or a third of carapace width. Mesotergal areas II-IV entire (except Sabanilla , with areas divided by a longitudinal gro ove); area II invading area I. Pedipalp s shorter than DS, stout, with the patella of almost same length as the tibia. Leg I normally build (not filiform). Legs III -IV clearly thicker than I -II, granular. Branches of MS-B minute ( G. rubrofemoratus ) or evident ( G. weyrauchi new comb. ). MS -E aligned horizontally ( G. rubrofemoratus ), or vertically ( G. weyrauchi new comb. ), in Sabanilla unknown. Stylus of penis with dorsal keel (in Globibunus , in Sabanilla unknown).
Distribution. Andes of Peru, Ecuador and Colombia.

Remarks . The genera Andrescava and Sabanilla are transferred from Leiosteninae to Globibuninae, and Andrescava must be synonymized with Globibunus. Three species, currently in Leiosteninae, must be transferred to Globibuninae: Avima olmosa (Roewer, 1956) , that must be transferred to Globibunus; and “Avima” scabra (Roewer, 1963) and “Avima” octomaculata (Roewer, 1963), that are considered genera incertae sedis . The internal relationships of Globibuninae are not the scope of the present work so, posterior analysis focusing in that topic are needed, including the description of the male penis of Sabanilla and the three Avima species mentioned above. For now, comp lementary descriptions based on the holotypes of Andrescava weyrauchi Roewer, 1957 , Andrescava sturmi Roewer, 1963 and Sabanilla ornata Roewer, 1913 are given.
SABANILLA ROEWER, 1913 NEW SUBFAMILY ASSIGNMENT (Figures 1 -3) Sabanilla Roewer 1913: 143; Roew er 1923: 450; Mello -Leitão 1926: 347; Roewer 1929:
Type species. Sabanilla ornata Roewer, 1913, by monotypy. Examined by photograph .
Placement. Sabanilla originally in Gonyleptidae Prostygninae. Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Kury (1993).

Etymology. Sabanilla from place name Sabanilla. Gender feminine. Diagnosis. DS granular. Ocularium high, without median concavity. Mesotergal areas I–IV divided by a longitudinal groove. Halves of areas II and IV subdivided in two minor areas. Proximal subareas of area II invading area I.
Sabanilla ornata Roewer, 1913 (Figures 1 -3) Sabanilla ornata Roewer 1913: 144, fig. 64; Roewer 1923: 451, fig . 567; Soares, Soares

Type data. 2 ♂ syntypes. “VENEZUELA, Sabanilla” (SMF RI 837/36), examined by photograph (Fig. 3). Extrapolated to be “COLOMBIA” by Kury (2003), but possible correct pl ace is ECUADOR: ZAMORA -CHINCHIPE , Sabanilla.

Remarks. In the description of various species, Roewer (1913; 1923) inconsistently cited Sabanilla either as being in “Kolumbien” or in “Venezuela”. Sabanilla, in this case probably refers to a small village ca lled Sabanilla ( -4.03333 º -79.01667 º, ca. 1500 m), on the old road between Loja –Zamora (Zamora -Chinchipe, southern Ecuador), rather than Colombia or Venezuela.

Complementary description (Fig. 3). DS granular. Ocularium high, without median concavity, gran ulate and unarmed (Fig. 3A). Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas: areas I –IV divided by a longitudinal groove, halves of areas II and IV subdivided in two minor areas. Proximal subareas of area II invading area I. Areas III and IV with a pair of paramedian tubercles, (Fig . 3B). Posterior margin of DS straight. Free tergites I –III with granules. Cheliceral hand swollen. Pedipalpal segments stout. Legs I –IV with similar thickness (leg I not filiform ), unarmed. Trochanters II and III with dorsodistal tubercles. Fe IV one and a half times DS length (Figs 3A,B). Penis unknown.
“Avima” scabra (Roewer, 1963) Incertae sedis (Figures 1, 2, 4C-D) Vimula scabra Roewer 1963: 48; Flórez & Sánchez 1995: 369.
o Trinella scabra : Pinto -da-Rocha 1996: 320; Kury 2003: 33. o Avima scabra : Villarreal -M. & Kury 2009: 67.

Type data. COLOMBIA: CUNDINAMARCA , Bogotá, East side, 2900 –3000 m, Complementary description (Fig. 4C). Margins of DS with granules. Ocularium high, granular and without median concavity. Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas: area I divided in two halves; areas II –IV undivided. Pedipalpal segments stout. Legs increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV. Coxa I ent irely visible in dorsal view. Legs III and IV with granules. Fe IV same length as DS length. Penis unknown.

“Avima ” octomaculata (Roewer, 1963) Incertae sedis Vimula octomaculata Roewer 1963: 48, figs 9 –10. o Trinella octomaculata : Pinto -da-Rocha 1996: 319; Kury 2003: 33. o Avima octomaculata : Villarreal -M. & Kury 2009: 66.
Type data. PERU: CAJAMARCA , 50 km N Cutervo, near Cueva San Andrés, [-6.38079º -78.812036 º] 2650 m, subtropical rainforest. ♂ holotype ♀ paratype (SMF 13944), not examined.

Remarks. I didn´t examine fresh material of the species and for that, no complementary description is given here. However, the original description allows knowing that the species belongs to Globibuninae.

GLOBIBUNUS ROEWER 1912 Globibunus Roewer 1912: 165; Roewer 1 923: 124; Mello -Leitão 1926: 330; Roewer 1928: 537; Mello -Leitão 1932: 41; Mello -Leitão 1935 b: 93; Mello -Leitão 1938: 143; Rambla 1978b: 304; Kury 1994: 140; Pinto -da-Rocha & Hara 2009: 36 [type species: Globibunus rubrofemoratus Roewer, 1912, by monotypy]. Andrescava Roewer, 1957: 76; Roewer 1963: 50; Rambla 1978b: 304; Kury 2003: 30 [type species: Andrescava weyrauchi Roewer, 1957, by original designation]. NEW SYNONYM Y
Etymology. From Latin globus (sphere) + Greek βουνός (mound). Gender masculine.

Placement. Globibunus originally in Phalangodidae Tricommatinae. Transferred to Cranaidae Prostygninae by Kury (1994: 140). Transferred to Agoristenidae Zamorinae by Pinto -da-Rocha & Har a (2009). Designated as type of the Agoristen idae Globibuninae by Included species: Sabanilla ornata Roewer, 1913, Globibunus rubrofemoratus Roewer, 1912, Globibunus sturmi (Roewer, 1963) comb. nov. , Globibunus weyrauchi (Roewer, 1957) comb. n ov., Globibunus olmosus (Roewer, 1956) comb. nov. Incertae sedis: “Avima” scabra (Roewer, 1963) , “Avima” octomaculata (Roewer, 1963).

Globibunus sturmi Roewer, 1963 NEW COMBINATION (Figures 1, 2, 5) Andrescava sturmi Roewer 1963: 50, not figured; Kury 2003: 30. o “Andrescara sturmi ” [incorrect subsequent spelling]: Flórez & Sánchez 1995: 369.

Type data . COLOMBIA: HUILA , Resina, [Guadalupe, vereda Resinas, 1.923561 º - 75.690955 º], 1600 –1800 m, under rotten log, 6.vi.1956, Sturm leg., 1 ♂ holotype (SMF 12703), examined by photograph (Fig. 5C). ♀ paratype, same data as holotype, (SMF Complementary description (Fig . 5). Anterior margin of DS smooth, posterior and lateral margins of DS granular. Ocularium high, without median concavity, granulate and unarmed (Figs 5A,B). Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas, granular and unarmed; area I, III and IV divided longitudinally; area II undivided, invading area (Figs 5A,B). Posterior margin of DS with marked corners. Free tergites I –III with granules (Fig. 5B). Cheliceral hand swollen. Pedipalpal segments stout. Legs I –IV with similar thickness, unarmed. Fe IV twice DS length. Penis unknown.

Globibunus olmosus (Roewer, 1956 ) NEW COMBINATION (Figures 1, 2, 4A,B) Avima olmosa Roewer 1956 : 438, fig. 10; Soares & Soares 1982: 27; Villarreal -M. & o Trinella olmosa : Pinto -da-Rocha 1996: 319; Kury 2003: 33.

Type data. PERU: LAMBAYEQUE , West Andes, at km 35 road Olmos -Jaén, [- 6.22513 º -79.751913 º], 1 ♂ holotype (SMF 9703), examined by photograph (Fig. 4B) . 1 ♀ 2 juv. paratypes (SMF RII 9704), 3 ♂ paratypes (SMF RII 9705).

Complementary description (Fig. 4A). Anterior and lateral margins of DS with some granules. Ocularium high, granular and without median concavity. Mesotergum well delimited, divided in four areas: area I divided in two halves; areas II –IV undivided; area II with irregular anterior border and posterior border straight; area III with substraight anterior and posterior borders. Posterior margin of DS with marked corners. Free tergites I–III with granules. Cheliceral hand swollen. Pedipalpal segments stout, Pa and Ti almost the same length . Legs I-IV with similar thickness, granular. Fe IV same length as DS length. Penis unknown.
Globibunus weyrauchi Roewer, 1957 NEW COMBINATION (Figures 1 , 2, 6 ) Andrescava weyrauchi Roewer 1957: 76; Kury 2003: 30.

Type data . PERU: CAJAMARCA , Cueva de San Andr és, 30 km NE Cutervo, [ - 6.145611 º -78.716626 º], 2600 m, complete darkness on vertical walls, 1 ♂ holotype (SMF RII 11643/26), examined by photograph . 4 ♀ paratypes, same data as holotype, (SMF RII 11643/26); 9 ♂ ♀ paratypes, same data as holotype, (AMNH).

Complementary description (Fig. 6). Anterior margin of DS smooth, posterior and lateral margins granular. Ocularium high, without median concavity, granulate and unarmed (Fig. 6B). Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas, granular and unarmed; area I divided longitudinally, areas II –IV undivided; area II with irregular anterior border and posterior border straight, area III with substraight anterior and posterior borders, area IV with laterals curved anteriorly, reaching area III (Fig. 6A). Posterior m argin of DS with

marked corners. Free tergites I –III with granules (Fig. 6B). Cheliceral hand swollen. Pedipalpal segments stout. Legs I -IV with similar thickness, unarmed. Fe IV two and a half times DS length. Penis with small lamina parva (LP) (height le ss than width) and depressed, Apex with anterolateral ear -shaped corners (Fig. 6C). Hammer (malleus) with two pairs of branched MS -A; one pair of branched MS -B (Fig. 6C); MS -C absent; two pairs of short MS -D ; MS -E 2 large and trifid , MS -E 1 short and con ical, located slightly distal to MS -E2 on the ventral side of the LP. Stylus simple, elongated, and straight, surpassing the lamina parva, with longitudinal dorsal keel; dorsal keel rounded (Fig . 6C).
LEIOSTENINAE ŠILHAVÝ, 1973

Tricommatinae [part]: Roe wer 1923: 121; Goodnight & Goodnight 1942: 3; Avram & Prostygninae [part]: Roewer 1923: 449; Mello -Leitão 1940: 305. Leiosteninae Šilhavý 1973: 131; Avram 1977: 142; Soares & Avram 1981: 75; Soares & Avram 1982: 19; Avram 1987: 81; Gonzá lez-Sponga 1987: 435; Pinto -da-Rocha Angelininae González -Sponga 1987: 427 [ preocc. Angelinae Giglio -Tos, 1927]. Synonymy established by Kury, 1997.
Angelinae [corrected spelling]: Kury 1993: 131.

Emended d iagnosis . DS Epsilon type , coloration varying between brown to pale yellow (in some cases with white/yellowish blots ). Individuals of different sizes (DS+LegIV length varies from less to 15 mm until 50 mm), with t egument finely granular (except in Muscopil io gen. nov. ). Ocularium on the middle of prosoma (except in Paravima and Muscopilio gen. nov. where is close to anterior border) mostly unarmed and low. Mesotergal areas unarmed (except in Barinas , Barlovento , Eyabida gen. nov. , Leptostygnus, Lionza gen. nov., Muscopilio gen. nov. , Ocoita , Paravima and Taulisa ). Mesotergal area I generally divided in two halves. Free tergites unarmed (except in Muscopilio gen. nov. and Taulisa ). Chelicerae sexually dimorphic (swollen in males). Pedipalpal segments slender (except in Leptostygnus and Muscopilio gen. nov. ), pedipalp usually longer than DS length, with femora and patellae bearing a mesodistal spin iform

tubercle (in Agoristeninae and Globibuninae small , in Rivetininae subf. nov . absent ). Leg IV mostly straight (except in Barlovento ), without tarsal process. Penis with horned -like LP, ear -shaped ( Avima , Balrog gen. nov. , Lionza gen. nov. , Tegua gen. nov. , Nemastygnus , Otrera gen. nov. ) or crescent -shaped ( Barinas , Barlovento , Eyabida gen. nov., Jaibana gen. nov. , Leptostygnus , Muscopilio gen. nov. , Ocoita , Pantariste gen. nov. , Paravima , Soroche gen. nov. and Vima ), unknown in Taulisa ; one pair of ventroapical MS-E1 short and simple (absent in Paravima , Pantariste gen. nov. and Eyabida gen. nov.) and one pair of branched MS -E2 (minute branches in some Globibuninae and Muscopilio gen. nov. , not branched in Rivetininae subf. nov. ), just below the MS -E1; one pair of ventro basal branched MS -B; two (in Paravima and Ocoita three pairs) of branched MS-A, that could be oriented transversally or oblique on malleus; two pair of MS -D on the laterodorsal space between the LP and the stylus; stylus straight or substraight (sinuous in Paravima ), mostly ornate (without dorsal keel or dorsal process in Parav ima, Eyabida gen. nov., Ocoita and Otrera soaresorum comb. nov. ).
Type genus. Leiostenus Šilhavý, 1973 (junior synonym of Avima Roewer, 1949). Distribution. Peru, Colombia, Brazil , Venezuela, Trinidad and Tobago, Gu yana and Suriname (Fig. 48).

Remarks. According to ICZN, art. 40.1, the subfamilial name Leiosteninae should not be changed, not even with the proposed synonymy of Leiostenus with Trinella (Kury 2003). The name Angelininae González -Sponga, 1987 [corrected or not to Angelinae] is invalid, beca use the type genus, Angela González -Sponga, 1987 is a homonym (Kury & Alonso -Zarazaga 2011: 49).

MUSCOPILIO VILLARREAL & GARCÍA GEN. NOV. (IN PRESS) Type species. Muscopilio onod sp. nov. , designated by monotypy. Etymology . From the Latin words muscus (= moss) + pre -existing genus Opilio . Gender masculine.

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon, type 4 (Fig. 7A). Ocularium densely tuberculated, with a pair of medial forward projected, large tubercles (Fig .7B). Mesotergal areas with conspicuous ornamentation, densely tubercu lated, having paired stout and tuberculated paramedian spines on area III (Figs 7A,B). Posterior border of DS and free tergites II –III with three medial large tubercles (Fig s 7B,C ). Anal operculum with two large tubercles (Figs 7B). Lateral and posterior b order of the DS rough in appearance, with a yellowish green spot (Figs 7A-D). Legs II –IV denselly tuberculated (Figs 7A,C ). Penis: Distal corners of the LP acute and curved (Figs 7E–G). Stylus with dorsal keel, without dorsal process ( Figs 7E,F). MS -E2 large and with minute branches (Fig. 7G). Included species. Muscopilio onod Villarreal & García, in press.

Muscopilio onod Villarreal & García, in press Etymology. In the fictional Sindarin language, created by J.R.R. Tolkien , Onod (plural Onodrim ) is the name given to the giant tree -like beings, also known as Ents. For us, the new species, greenish in color and with the legs covered by bryophytes, resembles an Onod. Noun in apposition.

LEPTOSTYGNUS MELLO -LEITÃO, 1 940 (Figure 1, 2, 49; Appendix III, García & Villarreal, 2020: figures 1 –9)

“Leptostygnu” [incorrect original spelling ] Mello -Leitão 1940: 305. Leptostygnus : Mello -Leitão 1949: 9; Soares, Soares & Jim 1992: 7; Kury 1993: 129; Kury Angela González -Sponga 1987: 427; Kury 1993: 129; Kury & Alonso -Zarazaga 2011: 49 [junior homonym of Angela Audinet -Serville, 1838 (Orthoptera) and of Angela Lesson, 1843 ( Cnidaria ); junior subjective synonym of Leptostygn us Mello - Leitão, 1940 by Kury (1997); type species: Angela marchantiarum González - Sponga, 1987, by original designation].
Type species. Leptostygnus leptochirus Mello -Leitão, 1940, by original designation.

Placement . Originally in Gonyleptidae Prostygninae. Transferred to Agoristenidae Angelinae by Kury (1993: 129), and later to the Leiosteninae by Kury (1997). Etymology . Leptostygnus from Greek λεπτός (slender) + pre -existing genus Stygnus . Gender masculine. Angela in honor of Angela Rosa Delg ado de González, collaborator of the author in field work. Gender feminine. Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 2, with white blots (except in L. leptochirus ). Scutal lateral margins densely granular. Mesotergal area III armed with a single medial spine or two par amedian almost fused spines, varying from acuminate, conical to mammilliform shape, being higher than ocularium. Pedipalps stout. Penis with distal corners of LP acute (crescent -shaped LP). MS -A-B bowed. Stylus sub -straight, with dorsal keeled expansion an d bended tip.
Included species. Leptostygnus leptochirus, Leptostygnus marchantiarum, Leptostygnus yarigui.
Distribution. Andes of Colombia and Venezuela.
Remarks. A recent revision of the genus was done by García & Villarreal, 2020 (see Appendix I II).
BARLOVENTO González -Sponga, 1987
Barlovento González -Sponga 1987: 436; Kury 1993: 131; Kury 1997: 344; Kury 2003 : 30; Kury & Alonso -Zarazaga 2011: 49.
Type species. Vima marmorata González -Sponga, 1981, by original designation. Placement. Originally in Leiosteninae.
Etymology. Barlovento is masculine by application of Art. 30.2.1, being a masculine Spanish word (Kury & Alonso -Zarazaga 2011: 49).

Diagnosis. Medium -sized animals (DS + Leg IV length = 15 -35 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2. Oculariu m low, granulate, without medial concavity , being half of carapace width . Mesotergal area III with paramedian spines of same high or higher than ocularium . Fe IV curved and stout , Ti IV twice Pa IV length . MS-A-B of penis transversally aligned. Stylus of penis sub-straight, with dorsal keel ed expansion .
Included species. Barlovento bubonicus new comb. , Barlovento albapatella, Barlovento lit torei, Barlovento marmoratus, Barlovento salmeronensis.

Complementary description. DS Epsilon type 2. Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth, posterior margin with a row of tubercles (Fig. 8A). Ocularium low, granulate, without median concavity (Figs 8C,D). Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas: area I

divided longitudinally, areas II –IV undivided; area s I, II and IV with a pair of paramedian tubercles, area III with a pair of paramedian spines (same height as ocularium) (Figs 8C,D). Posterior margin of DS substraight , with marked corners (Fig . 8B). Free tergites I – III with granules. Cheliceral hand swollen. Legs increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV, but legs III and IV at least two times thicker than legs I and II (Fig . 8A); legs III and IV with some granules. Fe IV two times DS length , Ti IV twice Pa IV length (Fig. 8E). Penis with small lamina parva (LP) (height less than width), apex with anterolateral rounded corners (Fig . 8F). Hammer (mall eus) with two pairs of branched MS-A; one pair of branched MSB ( Figs 8F,G ); MS-C absent; MS-D absent (see Remarks); MS-E2 large and trifid , MS-E1 absent (see Remarks). Stylus elongated, slightly curved at distal portion, surpassing the lamina parva, with dorsal keeled expansion (Figs 8F,G ).

Remarks. The penis of the species was dr awn, with some differences , in two works of González -Sponga ( González -Sponga, 1981: 49, fig. 14; 1987: 447, figs 264 –265). I decided to use both illustrations in the complementary description (Figs 8F,G ). As note d in other genera/species described for him, he didn´t draw MS-D and MS-E1 in Barlovento .

VIMA HIRST, 1912 (Figure 1, 2, 52; Appendix IV , García & Kury (2020): figures 1 –8)

Type species. Vima insignis Hirst, 1912, by monotypy. Placement . Originally in Phalangodidae. Included in Tricommatinae by Roewer (1923). Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Soares & Avram (1981). Transferred to Angelinae by Kury (1993). Transferred to Leiosteninae by Pinto -da-Rocha (1996). Etymology . Origin obscure.

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsylon type 1. Body coloration dark brown. Ocularium low, smooth, without median concavity. Mesotergal areas smooth (in V. insignis a hump on areas II -III). LP of penis with acute corners ( crescent shaped). Stylus elongated, straigth and with acuminate dorsal process.
Included species. Vima insignis, Vima panita.
Remarks. A recent revision of the genus was done by García & Kury, 2020 (see Appendix I V).
BARINAS González -Sponga, 1987 (Figure 1, 2, 49; Appendix V, Ahumada et al., 2020: figures 1 –9)
Barinas González -Sponga 1987: 453; Kury 1997: 344; Kury 2003: 30; Ahumada -C. et al.
Type species . Barinas flava González -Sponga, 1987, by original designation. Placement. Originally in Leiosteninae.

Etymology. From place name Barinas. Gender femini ne as used by the author. Diagnosis. Small animals (DS + Leg IV length = 15 -25 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Ocularium low, with paired armature (small tubercles or spines). Mesotergal areas I–IV with paramedian spines. Stylus elongated, curved dorsally at distal portion, with dorsal process and sometimes with connective tissue between the stylus and the DP (Barinas virginis new comb. ).
Included species. Barinas flava, Barinas piragua , Barinas virginis new comb. Remarks. A recent revision of the genus was done by Ahumada et al. (2020) (see Appendix V).

TAULISA ROEWER, 1956 (Figure s 47D, 52 )
Taulisa Roewer 1956: 433; Rambla 1978: 304; Kury 2003: 145; Pinto -da-Rocha et al.
Type species. Taulisa koepckei Roewer, 1956, by original designation. Examined by photograph .

Placement . Originally in Phalangodidae Tricommatinae. Transferred to Gonyleptidae Metasarcinae by Kury (2003). Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Pinto -da-Rocha et al. (2012). Etymology . From locality name (Hacienda) Taulis. Gender feminine.

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Ocularium unarmed, without median concavity . Mesotergal areas I –IV undivided, with a pair of paramedian tubercles or spines. Legs I –IV with similar thickness.

Remarks. I didn´t consider the species of Lionza gen. nov. as members of Taulisa , mainly because of the lack of genital information of the latter (only known exemplar is the female holotype), and the geographic distribution ( Taulisa is the only Leiosteninae that reaches Peru, see Fig. 52), while Lionza gen. nov. is found in Northern Venezuela (Fig. 51). Then, I prefer to maintain Taulisa as a monotypic genus until new information related to the male is available.
Taulisa koepckei Roewer, 1956 (Figures 47D, 52)

Ped ipalp with slender articles, its femur with dorsoapical spiniferous tubercle, with a row of four ventral large setae; pedipalpal patella with prolateral large spiniferous tubercle; pedipalpal tibia –tarsus with ectal -mesal large spiniferous tubercle. Legs I –IV with similar thickness, but leg I slightly slender than the others; Ta I three -segmented; dorsodistal tubercle of coxa IV dorsally projected. Fe IV one and a half times DS length. Male unknown.

Penis with distal corners of LP acute (crescent -shaped) . Distal half of stylus curved, slightly concave. Stylus sub-straight, with smooth dorsal keeled expansion . MS-A2 close to the base of the stylus. MS -A-B aligned transversal on malleus (L. palpogranulosa new comb. ) or oblique ( Lionza severa new Distribution. In Venezuela, Cordillera de la Costa , Aragua and Miranda states Included species. Lionza palpogranulosa new comb. , Lionza severa new comb.

PANTARISTE NEW GENUS Type species. Avima bicoloripes Roewer, 1949 .
Etymology. Pantariste was a brave Amazon who fought alongside Hippolyta against Heracles and his troops. Gender feminine.

Diagnosis. Large animals (DS + Leg IV length = 37 -50 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low , smooth and with out median concavity. Body with light background coloration ( P. bicoloripes new comb. and P. glabrata new comb. ) or dark ( P. albimaculata new comb. ). Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas, with dark blots covering almost entirely the areas (P. bicoloripes new comb. ), white blots on laterals of carapace (P. albimaculata new comb. ) or without blots ( P. glabrata new comb. ). Area I divided in two halves . Penis with distal corners of LP acute. MS -A2 far from the base of the stylus. MS-E1 absent (dubious in P. glabrata new comb. ). Distal half of stylus curved, markedly concave. Stylus with keeled dorsal expansion expanding beyond its apical point of union with stylus . Distribution. Amazon region of Brazil and Venezuela (Fig. 52) Included species. Pantariste bicoloripes new comb. , Pantariste glabrata new comb. , Pantariste albimaculata new comb.

Pantariste bicoloripes Roewer, 1949 NEW COMBINATION Avima bicoloripes Roewer 1949: 58; Soares & Soares 1982: 27; Villarreal -M. & Kury o Trinella bicoloripes : Pinto -da-Rocha 1996: 317; Kury 2003: 32.
Type data. BRAZIL: PARÁ, Belém, [ -1.430524 º -48.433751 º], 1 ♂ holotype (SMF 1535), examined .

Complementary description. Male holotype (SMF 1535) measurements: DSL= the original description the length of legs I -IV is 13/42/19/36 mm). Dorsum . DS Epsilon type 2 (Figs 13B, 14A ). DS with a clear medial longitudinal region beginning at posterior margin of the ocularium and reaching the posterior margin of the DS (Figs 13A–C). Paired dark spots occupying almost entirely the mesotergal areas (Figs 13A,B, 14A,B) Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low, smooth and without median concavity. (Figs 13B–D). Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas: area I divided in two halves; areas II –IV undivided (Figs 14A,B ). Posterior margin of scutum substraight with few granules (Figs 13B–D, 14A,B ). Free tergites I –III with some granules (Fig. 13B, 14A,B ). Venter . Coxa I with one high trapezoidal tubercle on the proximal region of the anterior margin and one media longitudinal row of small tub ercles (Fig s 13E, 14C ); coxae II–IV with some granules; coxa II longer than coxa I; coxa III longer than coxae I and II; coxa IV backward projected. Stigmata oval and transverse (Fig. 13E). Chelicera . Hand swollen. BaCh with well -marked bulla and two ectal tubercles (Figs 13B–D). Hand with setiferous tubercles of different sizes (reaching the medial and posterior region of the hand), and with one tubercle near the joint of the movable finger. Fixed finger with the inner surface finely grooved. Movable finge r with one trapezoid, sub -basal tooth and with a dentate distal inner surface (Fig. 14D). Pedipalps . Trochanter with one subapical tubercle on the ventral face. Femur with a ventroectal row of four setiferous tubercles and one large ventromesal setiferous tubercle in the apical portion (Figs 13B–D, 14E ). Patella with one large mesal setiferous tubercle (Fig. 14E) . Tibia ectal i IIi, mesal IIi. Tarsus ectal II i, mesal IIi. Legs . Increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV, smooth (Fig. 13A). Leg I filiform; coxa I with one dorsoanterior and one dorso posterior tubercle (Fig. 13D). Coxa II with one dorsomedial tubercle. Coxa III with one anterior tubercle. Coxa IV with a dorsodistal tubercle laterally projected; Fe IV length three times DS length (Fig . 13A). Ta I–II each with one smooth claw; Ta III –IV with two subparallel smooth claws and without tarsal process. Penis (Fig. 14F). LP small (width twice the height) and depressed, with anterolateral acute corners dorsally pointed. Malleus with two pairs of branch ed MS -A,

MS-A2 far from the base of the stylus; one pair of branched MS -B; MS -C absent; two pairs of short MS -D located in a keel between the ventral part of the LP and the base of the stylus; MS -E2 large and trifid ; MS -E1 absent. Distal half of stylus curved, markedly concave. Stylus with keeled dorsal expansion expanding beyond its apical point of union with stylus . Color (in alcohol) . Laterals of carapace, free tergites and legs Dark Yellow (88). Areas I –IV Light Yellow (86). Center of carapace and ch elicerae Pale Yellow (89) Remarks. The left pedipalp and some segments of the right pedipalp are detached from the body. The male genital was much deteriorated (broken) and just a photograph on lateral view was obtained .

OCOITA GONZÁLEZ -SPONGA, 1987
Ocoita González -Sponga 1987: 456; Kury 1997: 344; Kury 2003: 31.
Type species. Ocoita mina González -Sponga, 1987, by original designation. Placement. Originally in Leiosteninae.

Etymology . From the village El Mango de Ocoita, Miranda state, Venezuela. Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 2. Ocularium low, smooth, with median concavity. Mesotergal areas ill defined, areas I –IV entire, areas I, II and IV with pa ired paramedian granules, area III with a pair os spines. Coxa IV with a dorso -distal tubercle dorsally projected. Stylus of penis with dorsal keel. Included species. Ocoita mina, Ocoita tapipensis.
Remark. The complementary descriptions of the species do not repeat the generic characteristics. Villarreal et al . (in press) synonymized Ocoita servae with Ocoita tapipensis.
Ocoita mina González -Sponga, 1987 (Figures 17, 49 )
Ocoita mina González -Sponga 1987: 4 57, figs 579 –585; Kury 2003: 31.

Type data . VENEZUELA: MIRANDA , Brión, environs of Birongo, [10.482404 ° - 66.169586 °], 150 m, A.R. Delgado de González, J.A. González Delgado & M.A. González -Sponga leg ., 1 ♂ holotype (MCNC 957), not examined ; ♀ paratype (MCNC 958), ♂ ♀ paratypes (MAGS), same data as holotype.

Remarks . A male exemplar (MAGS 394) deposited in MIZA collection was examined (Fig. 17) and used for the complementary description. I suspect that this male corresponds to the male para type cited above as MAGS, without number. Complementary description (Figs 17A–E). Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Posterior margin of DS substraight, with a row of tubercles. Free tergites I –III with granules. Anterior margin of coxa I with a h igh proximal tricapitated tubercle.

Cheliceral hand swollen. Legs increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV; legs III and IV with some granules. Fe IV two and a half times DS length. Penis with small lamina parva (LP) (height less than width), apex with anterolateral crescent -shaped corners (Fig. 17E, see Remarks). M alleus with three pairs of branched MS -A; one pair of branched MSB (Fig. 17E); MS -C absent; MS -D absent (see Remarks); one pair of MS-E2 large and triffid, MS-E1 absent (see Remarks). Stylus elongated, straight, slightly curved at distal portion, surpassing the lamina parva; stylus wi th a basal expansion (Fig. 17E, see Remarks). Remarks. From all the drawings of a penis done by G-S, these are maybe the most challenging to understand, for the following reasons: (1) G-S shows a pair of strange branched setae (marked with a red interrogation in Fig. 17E) in the ventro -lateral region of the LP, where normally there are no setae, at least not in Leiosteninae (curiously, he made the same for the other species of Ocoita ); (2) in the lateral view of the penis (left drawing in Fig. 17E) the anterolateral corners of the LP seems to be crescent -shaped. However, in the ventral view of the penis ( right drawing in the same figure) it seems to be ear -shaped. So, I decided to follow the first option (it seems to be the same case for the other species of Ocoita ); (3) as in other genera/species described in the same work, G-S didn´t draw MS-D and MS-E1 in Ocoita mina ; (4) in the lateral view of the penis there is a wider area at the base of the stylus, not seen in other genera of Leiosteninae , that seems to be autapomorphic for the genus (s ee discussion section for more details ).

[10.229826 ° -66.084180 °], 50 m, A.R. Delgado de González, J.A. Male exemplar s of O. tapipensis (MAGS 728) and O. servae (MAGS 729) deposited in MIZA collection w ere examined (Fig. 18) and used for the complementary description. I suspect that th ese male s correspond to those cited as paratypes above as MAGS, without number. González -Sponga differentiated O. tapipensis from O. servae based mainly in the presence of a granule in the anteroproximal tubercle of coxa I and the granulation of mes otergal areas in the latter. However, I found the same kind of granulation (two paramedian granules) on areas I, II and IV, and a simple tubercle on coxa I (without conspicuous granule) in both species.

Complementary description ( Fig. 18). Anterior and la teral margins of DS smooth. Posterior margin of DS substraight. Free tergites I –III with granules. Anterior margin of coxa I with a high proximal conical curved tubercle. Cheliceral hand swollen. Legs increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV; legs III and IV with some granules. Fe IV two times DS length.
PARAVIMA CAPORIACCO, 1951 Paravima Caporiacco 1951: 11; Soares & Avram 1981: 76; González -Sponga 1987: 469; Paraavima (incorrect subsequent spelling): Soares & Avram 1981: 76.

Type species. Paravima goodnightorum Caporiacco, 1951, by monotypy. Placement . Originally in Tricommatinae. Transferred to Leiosteninae by Soares & Etymology . from Greek παρά (beside) + pre -existing genus Vima . Gender feminine.

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 3 . Ocularium low, very close to the anterior margin of DS, smooth and with median concavity. Mesotergal area III without paramedian ornamentation ( P. plana comb. nov. , P. quirozi comb. nov. and P. vigirima comb. nov.) or with paramedian ornamentation. Coxa IV with a dorso -distal tubercle dorsally projected. Penis with laterals of LP acute; space between MS -E and horned LP concave and narrow;

malleus with three pairs of branched MS-A; MS -E1 absent; MS-d present and medium - sized; stylus sigmoidal, without dorsal ornamentation. Distribution. In Cordillera de la Costa Mountain range (Northern Venezuela), in Distrito Federal, Aragua, Miranda, Guárico and Ya racuy states. Included species. Paravima goodnightorum , Paravima acanthoconus , Paravima flumencaurimarensis , Paravima locumida , Paravima morritomacairensis , Paravima propespelunca, Paravima plana new comb. , Paravima quirozi new comb. , Paravima vigirima new comb.
Remark. The complementary descriptions of the sp ecies do not repeat the generic characteristics.

OTRERA NEW GENUS Type species. Avima matintaperera (Pinto -da-Rocha, 1996) Etymology. Otrera was the warrior that created the Amazon Nation . According to Hyginus (64 BC –17 AD), Otrera and her people were warlike women whose skills in battle were not matched by any man. Gender feminine.

Diagnosis. Medium -size animals (DS + Leg IV length = 26 -36 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low, smooth and with median concavity. Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas, with dark blots covering almost entirely the areas. Area I divided in two halves. Coxae IV with a dorsoapical large tubercle. Penis with distal corners of LP acute ( O. soareso rum comb. nov. and O. anitas comb. nov. ) or rounded ( O. matintaperera comb. nov. ). MS -A2 close to the base of the stylus. Distal half of stylus curved, slightly concave. Stylus straight or sub-straight, with smooth dorsal keeled expansion ( O. matintaperera comb. nov. and O. anitas comb. nov. ) or without expansion ( O. soaresorum comb. nov. ). Included species. Otrera anitas comb. nov. , Otrera matintaperera comb. nov. , Otrera soaresorum comb. nov.

Type data. BRAZIL: RORAIMA , Serra do Tepequém, [3.750303 ° -61.740686 °], 1 ♂ holotype (INPA 3399), examined.

Complementary description. DS Epsilon type 2 (Fig. 27A). Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low, smooth and with median concavity. Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas: area I divided in two halves; areas II –IV undivided; area III with a pair of paramedian granules; areas III –IV with two circular dark spots covering two thirds of each area (Figs 27B–D). Anterior margin of coxa I with a proximal bifid tubercle (Fig. 27E). Cheliceral hand swollen. Pedipalpal segments slender (Fig. 27D). Legs increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV, unarmed. Leg I filiform. Fe IV three and a half times DS length (Fig. 27A). Penis (Fig. 29, modified from figures 6 –8 in Porto & Colmena res, 2014): LP small (width twice the height) and depressed, with anterolateral acute corners dorsoapically pointed (figs. 6 –8). Malleus with two pairs of branched MS -A; one pair of branched MS B; MS-C absent; two pairs of short MS-D located in a keel betw een the ventral part of the LP and the base of the stylus; MS-E2 large and triffid, MS - E1 short, conical and branched, located distal to MS -E 2 on the ventral side of the LP . Stylus elongated, mostly straight (curved dorsally at the apex), and surpassing t he lamina parva; dorsal keel present, with the distal m argin finely corrugated .
NEMASTYGNUS ROEWER, 1929
Nemastygnus Roewer 1929: 277; Mello -Leitão 1932: 108; Kury 2003 : 145; Pinto -da- Rocha et al. 2012: 28 (diagnosis).
Type species. Nemastygnus ovalis Roewer, 1929, by monotypy.

Placement . Originally in Gonyleptidae Prostygninae. Later in Cranaidae Prostygninae (Kury 1994: 140); then in Gonyleptidae Metasarcinae (Kury 2003 ). Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Pinto -da-Rocha et al. (2012). Etymology. From Greek nema (= string) , referring to the filiform leg I + Stygnus (pre-existing genus of harve stmen).

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 1. Body with dark background coloration. Ocularium low, unarmed, with median concavity. Mesotergal areas, posterior margin of DS and free tergites unarmed. Legs III -IV clearly thicker than the others. Fe IV large (more than 7 mm), granular. Stylus of penis with striated dorsal keel , hand fan -like; apical border of dorsal keel elevated at medial region and without dorsaoapical sharp tooth . Included species. Nemastygnus ovalis, Nemastygnus guache sp. nov.
Nemastygnus ovalis Roewer, 1929 (Figure s 30, 53 )
Nemastygnus ovalis Roewer 1929: 277, fig. 44; Flórez & Sánchez 1995: 369; Kury 2003: 145; Pinto -da-Rocha et al. 2012: 29, fig. 1 (genitalia).

Type data . COLOMBIA: [CUNDINAMARCA ], Bogota, [4.686965 ° -74.030882 °], ♂ holotype (SMF RI 1005/4) , examined by photograph (Figs 30A -C). Complementary description (augmented from Pinto -da-Rocha et al . 2012) . Measurements (based on figure 1A, less FeIV) : DSL= 2.5, CL= 1. 1, CW= 1. 8, AL= 1. 4, AW= 2.1, IOD= 0. 7, BaCh= 0.4, PeL= 3.7, Fe IV= 9.5. Mesotergum delimited, divided in four areas: area I –IV undivided ( Figs 30A, B). Cheliceral hand swollen in male. Pedipalp segments slender; Fe without dorsoapical spine, with row of three ventral large setae and

two ventroapical large setae; patella with prolateral large setae; tibia –tarsus with ectal - mesal large setae. Legs I filiform, [tarsus] three -segmented. Fe IV three times the length of DS (Fig. 30B). Penis (Fig. 30D) with small LP (height less than width), apex with anterolateral ear -shaped project ions. Malleus with two pairs of branched MS-A, being the MS-A2 far from the base of the stylus ; one pair of branched MSB ; MS-C absent; two pairs of short MS -D located on the dorsal curve of the LP, close to the base of the stylus ; MS-E2 large and triffid, MS-E1 present, simple . Stylus, elongated, curved at distal portion, surpassing the LP, with a small ventral crest and a striated dorsal keel.
Distribution . Central Andes of Colombia, Cundinamarca department (Fig. 53).

Nemastygnus guache NEW SPECIES Etymology. Guache (from Muysccubun , the language of the Muiscas, Indian people that inhabited the central highlands of Colombia) means lord. The Spanish conquerors, to disparage the Indians, gave a negative meaning to the word, being synonymous of “person without manners , vulgar ”. Noun in apposition. Type data. COLOMBIA : CUNDINAMARCA , Gutiérrez, Quebrada La Lejía, 1973 ); same data as holotype, 2 ♂ 1 ♀ paratypes (MNRJ 60310) ; same data as holotype, 2 ♀ paratypes (ICN -Ao-1974 ); same data as holotype, 1 ♂ 1 ♀ paratypes (MUSENUV -Ar 2100 ); Gutiérrez, camino a la Quebrada La Lejía, sector Honduras, [4.251769° - Description. Male holotype ( ICN-Ao-1973 ). Dorsum . DS Epsilon type 1 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS finely granular . Ocularium low, smoot h and without median concavity (Figs 31A–D). Yellowish/white blot beginning at posterior region of carapace , going across the longitudinal axis of the mesotergum and reaching the posterior border of area IV ( Figs 31B,D ). Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas: area I divided in t wo halves; areas II –IV undivided (Fig. 31B,D). Posterior margin of scutu m substraight with few granules . Free tergites I –III with some granules (Figs 31C, E). Venter . Coxa I with a longitudinal row of tubercles (the two dis talmost larger than the others) an d a short row of tubercles on the anterior margin, being the most proximal trapezoidal , bicapitated and larger than the others ; coxae II –IV with some granules; coxa II longer than

coxa I; coxa III longer than coxae I and II; coxa IV backward projected. Sti gmata oval and transverse (Fig. 31E). Chelicera . Chelicera swollen. BaCh quadrate in dors al view, with well-marked bulla and at least 16 large tubercles scattered on all the surface , being those on mesal and posterior faces slightly curved . Hand with setif erous tubercles of different sizes on the poste rior region . Fixed finger with the inner surface finely grooved. Movable finger with one trapezoid, sub -basal tooth and with a dentate distal inner surface .

Pedipalps . Trochanter with one subapical tubercle on the ventral face. Femur with a ventroectal row of four setiferous tubercles (the two basalmost largest, the medial small, and the distalmost medium -sized) (Fig. 31D), and one large ventromesal setiferous tubercle in the apical portion (Fig. 31C). Patella with one large mesal setiferous tubercle. Tibia ectal i III, mesal IIi. Tarsus ectal II i, mesal II i (Figs 31C, D). Legs . Legs III -IV thicker than I -II, granulate (Fig. 31A). Leg I filiform; coxa I with one dorsoant erior and one dorso posterior tubercle. Coxa II with one dorso anterior and one retrolateral tubercle s. Coxa III with one dorsomedial and one retrolateral tubercles; Coxa IV with some distal tubercles; Fe I–IV with dispersed granules. Fe IV length three times DS length (Fig. 31A), with two dorsoapical tubercles ; Pa IV with a group of tubercles on dorsodistal margin ; Ta I –II each with one smooth claw; Ta III –IV with two subparallel smooth claws and without tarsal process. Penis . LP small (width twice the heig ht) and depressed, with anterolateral ro unded corners (ear -shaped) apically pointed (Figs 32A–E). Malleus with two pairs of branched MS-A, being MS -A2 located far to the base of the stylus ; one pair of branched MS-B (Figs
32A–C); MS-C absent; two pairs of medium -sized MS-D located in a keel between the

dorsal region of the LP and the base of the stylus (Figs 32A–D); MS-E2 large and triffid, MS-E1 medium -sized and conical, located distal to MS-E2 on the ventral side of the LP (Figs 32B,C, E). Stylus elongated , mostly straight (curved dorsally at the apex), and surpassing the LP; dorsal keel present, striated, with a n elevation at medial region (Fig. 32E); tip truncated, dorsally projected. Color (in alcohol) . Lateral borders of DS and BaCh Deep Brown (56). Mesotergum and posterior region of ocularium Dark Brown (59) .

Chelicera l hand , pedipalps and l egs I –IV Moderate Yellow (87). Posterior margin of DS and free tergite s Dark Olive (108) (Fig. 31). Remark. The living specimens exhibit a brilliant greenish coloration on the posterior margin of DS and free tergite s.

TEGUA NEW GENUS Type species. Tegua u-viride sp. nov ., by monotypy Etymology. The Tegua or Tecua were an indigenous people of Colombia who inhabited the territory were the species was collected. In Colombian Spanish, tegua means "shaman" or "witchdoctor", referring to the advanced knowledge the Tegua had of medicinal plants. Gender masculine.

Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 2. Body with opaque dark background coloration. Yellowish/greenish l ight blots on laterals of DS. Ocularium low, unarmed, without median concavity. Mesotergal areas, posterior margin of DS and free tergites unarmed. Legs III -IV clearly thicker than the others. Fe IV very large (more than 10 mm), smooth . Corners of LP short and rounded, dorsally pointing. Stylus of penis with smooth dorsal expansion , hand fan -like; apical border of dorsal keel elevated at medial region , with dorsoapical sharp tooth and thickened dorsal border .
Tegua u-viride NEW SPECIE S Etymology. The specific epithet refers to the U -shaped green blot on the DS of the species. Noun in apposition.

JAIBANA NEW GENUS Type species. Jaibana wayuu sp. nov.

Etymology. Jaibana is one of the Indigenous names given for a spiritual man, a witch -doctor, in Colombia. Gender masculine. Diagnosis. DS outline Epsilon type 4. Body with light background coloration. Ocularium high, granular , without median concavity. Mesotergal areas, posterior margin of DS and free tergites unarmed. Legs steadily ticker from I to IV. Corners of LP acute , dorsoapica lly pointing. Stylus of penis with smooth dorsal expansion, hand fan -like; apical border of dorsal keel elevated at medial region, with dorsaoapical sharp tooth and thickened dorsal border.
Included species. Jaibana wayuu sp. nov., Jaibana chiguaraensis new comb.

Jaibana wayuu NEW SPECIES Etymology. The Wayuu (also Wayu, Wayúu, Guajiro, Wahiro) is an indigenous American ethnic group that inhabit northwestern Venezuela and northeastern Colombia on the Guajira Peninsula. Noun in apposition.
Type data. COLOMBIA, LA GUAJIRA : Hato Nuevo, 11°7'51.5'' N 72°47'23.9'' W same data as holotype, 8 ♂ 11 ♀ (ICN -Ao-1718).

Descripti on. Male Holotype ( ICN-Ao-1976 ). Dorsum . DS Epsilon type 4 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low, smooth and without median concavity (Figs 35A–D). Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas: area I divided in two halves; areas II –IV undivided (Fig. 35D). Posterior margin of scutum substraight with few granules (Figs 35 B–D). Free tergites I –III with some granules (Figs 35C, E). Venter . Coxa I with a longitudinal row of tubercles and one large bicapitate tubercl es on the anteroproximal margin ; coxae II –IV with some granules; coxa II longer than coxa I; coxa III longer than coxae I and II; coxa IV backward projected. Stigmata oval, small and

transverse (Fig. 35E). Chelicera . Chelicera swollen. BaCh quadrate in dorsal view, with well-marked bulla, three mesal , five anterior and three ectal tubercles. Hand with setifero us tubercles of different sizes reaching the medial and posterior region . Fixed finger with the inner surface finely grooved. Movable finger with one trapezoid, small sub-basal tooth and with a dentate distal inner surface . Pedipalps . All segments slender than normal.

Trochanter with one subapical tubercle on the ventral face. Femur with a ventroectal row of four setiferous tubercles (the two basalmost largest and the two distalmost medium - sized), and one large ventromesal setiferous tubercle in the apical portion (Fig. 35E) . Patella with one large mesal setiferous tuber cle. Tibia ectal III, mesal I Ii. Tarsus ectal IIi, mesal IIi . Legs . Increasing in thickness from leg I to leg IV, smooth (Fig. 35A). Leg I filiform; coxa e I-III with one dorsoanterior and one dorso posterior tubercle s; Coxa IV with some prolaterodistal tub ercles; Fe III -IV darker than I -II. Fe IV length three and a half times DS length (Fig. 35A); Ta I –II each with one smooth claw; Ta III –IV with two subparallel smooth claws and without tarsal process. Penis . LP small (width twice the height) and depressed, with anterolateral acute corners (crescent -shaped) apically pointed (Figs 36A–E). Malleus with two pairs of branched MS -A, being MS -A2 far from the base of the stylus ; one pair of branched MS -B; MS-C absent; two pairs of medium -sized MS -D located in a ke el between the dorsal region of the LP and the base of the stylus (Figs 36A– C, E); MS -E2 large and branched, MS -E1 short and conical, located slightly distal to MS - E2 on the ventral side of the LP (Figs 36C,D ). SOROCHE NEW GENUS Type species. Soroche butulu sp. nov.
Etymology. Soroche is a colloquial Spanish word for the negative health effect of high altitude, caused by rapid exposure to low amounts of oxygen at high elevation. Gender masculine.

Diagnosis. Small animals (DS + Leg IV length = 15 -25 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium normal or slightly higher than normal, smooth (in S. granulosus new comb. granular), and without median concavity (in S. flavomaculatus with median concavity). Mesotergum slightly delimited, sometimes with light (S. flavomaculatus new comb. and S. subparamerus new comb. ) or dark blots (S. butulu sp. nov. and S. quadratus new comb. ). Penis with distal corners of LP acute. Stylus concave (in S. butulu sp. nov. hooked , in S. subparamerus new comb. convex ), with keeled rounded dorsal expansion and sharp apical projection (absent in S. subparamerus new comb. ).

Distribution. Eastern Range Mountain, in Colombian Andes, and Cordillera de Merida, In Venezuelan Andes (Fig. 51) Included species. Soroche butulu sp. nov. , Soroche quadratus new comb. , Soroche flavomaculatus new comb. , Soroche granulosus new comb. , Soroche subparamerus new comb.
Remarks. Villarreal et al . (in press) synonymized Avima nigromaculata (González -Sponga, 1998) with Avima quadrata (González -Sponga, 1998) , and here I transferred the later to Soroche gen. nov .
Soroche butulu NEW SPECIES Etymology. Butulu is the highest mountain of the municipality where the species was collected. Noun in apposition.

Hand with setiferous tubercles o f different sizes reaching the medial and posterior region s, and with one tubercle near the joint of the movable finger. Fixed finger with the inner surface finely grooved. Movable finger with one trapezoid, sub - basal tooth and with a dentate distal inner surface . Pedipalps . Trochanter with one subapical tubercle on the ventral face. Femur with a ventroectal row of four setiferous tubercles (the two basalmost largest, the medial small, and the distalmost medium -sized), and one large ventromesal setiferous tubercle in the apical portion (Fig s 37B, C, E). Patella with one large mesal setiferous tubercle. Tibia with a dark blot on dorsal surface; ectal iII, mesal IIi. Tarsus darker than the rest of the segments; ectal IIi, mesal IIi (Figs 37C, D). Legs . Increa sing in thickness from leg I to leg IV, smooth (Fig. 37A). Leg I filiform; coxa e I-II with one dorsoanterior and one dorso posterior tubercle. Coxae III -IV with one dorsomedial tubercle dorsally pointing ; Fe IV length two and a half times DS length (Fig. 37A); Pa IV with three dorsal tubercles on the distal margin ; Ta I –II each with one smooth claw; Ta III –IV with two subparallel smooth claws and without tarsal process. Penis . LP small (width twice the height) and depressed, with anterolateral sharp corners (crescent - shaped) dorsoapically pointed (Figs 38A–E). M alleus with two pairs of bowed and branched MS -A, being the MS -A2 close to the base of the stylus; one pair of branched MS-B (Figs 38A–C); MS -C absent; two pairs of short MS -D very close to each other ,

located in a keel between the dorsal region of the LP and the base of the stylus (Figs 38A– D); MS -E2 large and triffid, MS -E1 short and conical, located distal to MS -E2 on the ventral side of the LP (Figs 38B, C, E). Stylus elongated, curved dorsally at the apex (hooked), and surpassing the lamina parva (Figs 38C, E) ; dorsal keel present, rounded but slightly angulate, with a projection close to the dorsal surface (Fig. 38E) ; tip truncated, basally curved (Fig. 38F) . BALROG NEW GENUS Type species. Avima checkeleyi Etymology. Balrog is a tall and menacing fictional being of the J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle -earth, typically found in caves, as the species of the genus. Gender masculine. Diagnosis. Large to very large animals (DS + Leg IV length = more than 35 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 4 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low (sometimes reduced, eyes absent in B. bordoni and B. troglobius ), smooth and without median concavity. Mesotergum poorly delimited, divided in four smooth areas. Cheliceral sockets angulated and shallow. Pedipalps large (more than 5 mm). Legs III and IV clearly thicker than I and II. Penis w ith distal corners of LP rounded. Stylus straight or sub - straight, with hand fan -like dorsal expansion.

Distribution. In Serranía del Perija (shared between Colombia (La Guajira department) and Venezuela (Zulia state)), slopes of Cordillera de Mérida (Méri da state) and Northern Venezuela (Falcón state) (Fig. 50) Included species. Balrog azulitai new comb., Balrog checkeleyi new comb. , Balrog bordoni new comb. , Balrog chapmani new comb. , Balrog falconensis new comb. , Balrog troglobius new comb.

Type specie s. Avima leucobunus Roewer, 1949, by original designation. Placement. Avima , Trinella and Vimula originally in Phalangodidae Tricommatinae. Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Soares & Avram (1981). Leiostenus originally type of Agoristenidae Lei osteninae. Phalangozea originally in Phalangodidae. Transferred to Agoristenidae Leiosteninae by Šilhavý (1979: 330). Etymology. Trinella from place name Trin(idad) + Latin suffix –ella. Gender feminine. Avima and Vimula are obvious and unimaginative deri vations of Vima . Gender feminine. Leiostenus probably from Leio(bunus) (which Šilhavý thought resembled it) + truncation of (Agori)stenus. Gender masculine. Phalangozea from Phalango(didae) + (Cueva Francisco) Zea. Gender feminine.

Emended d iagnosis. Large to very large animals (DS + Leg IV length = more than 35 mm). DS outline Epsilon type 2 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. In some species ( A. leucobunus and A. venezuelica ) the DS present yellowish blots. Ocularium low, smooth and without median concavity. Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas. Pedipalps large (more than 5 mm). Penis with distal corners of LP rounded. Stylus straight or sub -straight, with smooth dorsal keeled expansion. Distribution. North of Colombia (La Gu ajira state) and Northwestern Venezuela (Falcón and Zulia states) ( A. venezuelica ); Northeastern Venezuela ( Monagas state), Trinidad and Tobago and Suriname (the other species).
Included species. Avima leucobunus , Avima intermedia , Avima leiobuniformis, Avima venezuelica.

Remarks. Avima has been used as the hodgepodge of the Leiosteninae, grouping 34 species with wide distribution and no systematic affinities, as mentioned in Porto & Colmenares (2014), García & Villarreal, (2020) an d García & Pastrana (in press), but just evidenced in the present analysis: there are Avima members in Globibuninae and in different related and unrelated genera across Leiosteninae (Fig. 1). However, the
redescription of the type species (only know by the original description of Roewer) and the draw of the penis, allowed to redefine Avima , now composed by the four species cited above.
