Redescription. Male Holotype (SMF 1533/8) Measurements: DSL= 3.0, CL= 1.3, Dorsum . DS Epsilon type 2 . Anterior and lateral margins of DS smooth. Ocularium low, smooth and without median concavity. Post -ocular region of carapace with elliptical hillock, provided with a yellowish lunate blot (Figs 42A–D, 43A , 44A –D, 47A ). Mesotergum slightly delimited, divided in four smooth areas: area I divided in two halves;

areas II –IV un divided (Fig s 42D, 43A ). Posterior margin of scutum substraight with few granules (Figs 42B–D, 43A, B). Free tergites I –III with some granules, free tergite III with a white elliptical blot (Fig s 43E, 44E ). Venter . Coxa I with a longitudinal row of tubercles (the distal one visible in dorsal view) and one conical large tubercle on the anteroproximal margin (the left Coxa I has two conical large tubercles) (Figs 42B, 43C, 44E ); coxae II –IV with some granules; coxa I I longer than coxa I; coxa III longer than coxae I and II; coxa IV backward projected. Stigmata oval and transverse (Fig s 42E, 44E ). Chelicera . Chelicera swollen. BaCh quadrate in dorsal view, with well-marked bulla, two ectal, three anterior and two mesal tubercles. Hand with setiferous tubercles of different sizes (reaching the medial and posterior region of the hand), and with one tubercle near the joint of the movable finger. Fixed finger with the inner surface finely grooved. Movable finger with one tr apezoid, sub -basal tooth and with a dentate distal inner surface (Fig. 43D). Pedipalps . Trochanter with one subapical tubercle on the ventral face. Femur with a ventroectal row of five setiferous tubercles (the two basalmost largest, the medial small, and the two distalmost medium -sized), and one large ventromesal setiferous tubercle in the apical portion (Figs 43E, F) . Patella with one large mesal setiferous tubercle. Tibia ectal iIII, mesal IIi. Tarsus ectal II i, mesal IIi(Figs 43E, F) . Legs . Increasing i n thickness from leg I to leg IV, smooth (Fig s 42A, 44A ). Leg I filiform; coxa I with one dorsoanterior and one dorso posterior tubercle s. Coxa II with one dorsomedial and one retrolaterl tubercle s. Coxa III with one anterior, one posterior and one large re trolateral tubercle s. Coxa IV with two small dorso distal tubercles; Fe IV length four times DS length ( Figs 42A, 44A ); Pa IV with one medium -sized tubercle on prolateral face, two large tubercles on prolateroventral face, and on large tubercle on retroventral face ; Ta I –II each with one smooth claw; Ta III – IV with two subparallel smooth claws and without tarsal process. Penis . LP small (width twice the height) and depressed, with anterolateral rounded corners (ear -shaped) dorsoapically pointed (Fig s 43G–H). Malleus with two pairs of branched MS -A; one pair of branched MS-B; MS -C absent; two pairs of short MS -D located in a keel between the ventral part of the LP and the base of the stylus ; MS -E 2 large and triffid, MS -E 1 short and conical, locate d slightly distal to MS -E 2 on the ventral side of the LP (Figs 43G –H). Stylus elongated, mostly straight (curved dorsally at the apex), and surpassing the lamina parva; dorsal keel present, with a tiny projection close to apical junction with the stylus (indicated by an arrow in Fig. 43G); tip truncated, dorsally projected. Color (in alcohol) . Carapace, chelicerae and pedipalps Moderate Orange Yellow (71). Lateral borders of DS
and free tergites Deep Yellowish Brown (75). Legs I –IV Dark Orange Yellow (72). Dorsal lunate blot Pale Yellow (89) (Fig. 42).

Remarks. In the description of A. albiornata , Goodnight & Goodnight (1947) stated that the species exhibits, posterior to the eye tubercle, “an elevation equal in height to the eye tubercle, but somewhat cons tricted in the middle” . Posteriorly, they describe “ A white dot in the median portion of the third free tergite”. By examination of the holotype of A. leucobunus (Fig. 42), and comparing with topotypical material of A. albiornata (Fig. 44), I propose that they must be synonymized. For the case of A. albidecorata (Šilhavý, 1979) (Fig. 47A) , Šilhavý (1979: 331, fig. 22) drew the elevation posterior to ocularium, the variations of the white blots on the DS, and the male genital (that is ident ical than those of A. leucobunus , except for the absence of the tiny projection in the dorsal keel). So, I consider that those characters are enough to propose the synon ymization of the three species.

 Stylus: The stylus in Leiosteninae can be sinuous (as in Paravima , Fig. 19F), bent 45 degrees (as in Barinas , Fig. 10F), or subs traight , being sometimes hooked at distal third (as in Tegua u-viride gen. et sp. nov. (Fig. 34D) and Soroche butulu sp. nov. (Fig. 38E)). In some cases, the stylus can be completely smooth, as in Paravima (Fig. 19F), Eyabida gen. nov. (Fig. 16A), Ocoita (Fig. 17E, that has a basal expansion but it is considered not homologous to a dorsal keel), and Otrera soaresorum comb. nov. , where is considered a reversion (see fig. 14 in Pinto -da-  Dorsal expansion /process: the majority of the Leiosteninae, the stylus have a dorsal expansion (keeled (Fig. 7F) or hand fan -like (Figs 32A, 34D )), or a dorsal process (DP) (as in Barinas (Fig. 10F) and Vima (García & Kury, 2020: fig. 4)). Here, I consider the dorsal keel and the DP as different characters, and the sporadic presence of a connective tissue between the dorsal process and the stylus as a separate character (chr. 118). It is visible in Barinas , where B. flava has just DP (Ahumada et al. 2020, fig. 1F) , B. piragua has DP with a structure that seems the beginning of the connective tissue (called dorsal hump in Ahumada et al. 2020, fig. 4d), and B. virginis comb. nov. (Fig. 10F) had a complete connective tissue between the DP and the stylus.

 MS-E1: The presence/absenc e of this macrosetae (chr. 95) defined a clade composed by Pantariste gen. nov. , Paravima and Eyabida gen. nov. (Ocoita has this character marked as “?” in the matrix because of ir is dubious in the penis drawing (Fig. 17E), so, it is grouped together thos e genera but for other characters). That macroseta is very small and passed unnoticed in a lot of G -S drawings: I reviewed three works of G -S (1981, 1987 and 1998 ) and found just four genital drawings showing the MS -E1). The revision of male genitalia for the rest of the

Leiosteninae can reveal new information about the presence of this MS, as happened with Otrera matintaperera comb. nov. , that according to the drawings of Pinto -da-Rocha (1996, fig. 12) lack MS -E1 but, in my revision of fresh material of the species (Fig. 28), that MS -E1 is present.

 MS-D: With some drawings and SEM images that show that MS, it was possible to detect difference in the size (chr. 93) (e.g. large, as in Paravima , Fig. 19F; medium - sized, as in Otrera gen. nov. , Figs 28 -29; small, as in Barinas piragua , Ahumada et al. 2020, fig. 4C,D). However, all the characters related to MS -D (chrs 91 -94) have a lot of missing data, especially because the original descriptions and the redescriptions rarely show that macroseta (e.g. Paravima plana comb. nov. , in Rambla, 1978: fig. 6; Jaibana chiguaraensi s comb. nov. , in González -Sponga, 1987: fig. 658), or sometimes just one pair was shown (e.g. Balrog checkeleyi comb. nov. , in González -Sponga, 1987: fig. 652) . I found some cases where the MS-D where very close one to the other (e.g. Nemastygnus ovalis , Fig. 30; Soroche butulu gen. et sp. nov. , Fig. 38C), but with the lack of information mentioned above it is impossible to define its phylogenetic signal.

 MS-A: Normally in Leiosteninae there are found two pairs of MS -A, with exception of the genera Paravima (e.g. P. goodnightorum , Figs 19F,G; P. plana comb. nov. , in Rambla, 1978: fig. 6 ) and Ocoita (Fig. 17E) , that exhibit three pairs. Besides that, the alignment of these MS on malleus tend to be obliquous (chr. 86:1), but in some unrelated species ( Avima albiornata , Balrog falconensis gen. nov., Lionza palpogranulosa comb. nov., Eyabida tuttifrutti comb. nov. ) and Agoristeninae (e.g. Agoristenus cubanus , Ahotta hispaniolica ) the MS -D have a transversal alignment (chr. 86:0, Fig. 16). In other cases, the more dorsal MS -A are displaced basally on malleus, far from the base of the stylus (e.g. Otrera anitas comb. nov. (Fig. 29), Nemastygnus guache sp. nov. ( Fig. 32F), Tegua u-viride gen. et sp. nov. (Fig. 34C)).

 MS-B: These are the only macrosetae that maintain their position ( on ventro lateral region of malleus) and the quantity (one pair) constant in Leiosteninae . That happens in Agoristeninae too, and varies in Globibunus (Kury & Villarreal, 2015: fig. 2) and Rivetinus (Pinto -da-Rocha & Hara, 2009: fig. 4E), where have a more distal position on malleus .

As a recommendation, more SEM imaging should be done with the male genitalia of Leiosteninae, because a lot of in formation (e.g. texture of stylus, shape and size of LP corners , sharp tooth on dorsal keel) passes unnoticed on optical microscopy.

The distribution and hidden diversity of Leiosteninae The updated geographical distribution of the Leiosteninae (Figs 48 -53) show a high degree of local diversity and specific endemism in almost all the genera, as proposed by Villarreal & García (2020) for Barlovento , Leptostygnus , Ocoita , and Paravima. Inter estingly, those genera, together with Soroche gen. nov. , Lionza gen. nov. and Nemastygnus , followed by Barinas and Balrog gen. nov., are, until now, present in the Andes of Venezuela and Colombia, with its species very close together. In the other hand, the genera associated to lowlands of eastern Venezuela and Colombia, Trinidad and Tobago, Guyan a, Suriname and Northern Brazil, seems to show a more wide distribution (e.g. Vima , Pantariste gen. nov. , Otrera gen. nov. , in Fig. 52).

Both “patterns” must be a nalyzed carefully, mainly because of the lack of information about Agoristenidae (ecology, preferred habitats) and the undersampling of regions as the Amazon and Andes. As an example, the genus Vima , which was known for a lot of time as endemic from Guyana , had a second species recently described from the eastern lowlands of Colombia, 1500 km to the southwest (García & Kury, 2020 , Appendix IV). However, even when it seems a huge distribution range for a harvestman, the climatic conditions seems to support t he broad extension of the genus (García & Kury, 2020: fig. 8), and at the same time, show us the need of more collecting efforts in such areas. Then, I think that taxonomic and ecologic works focused in such taxa are gradually showing the preferring microh abitats where the Leiosteninae are found. For example, it seems that Barinas are found mainly on the leaf litter and rotten trunks close to the forest soil (at least it was seen in the collecting expeditions in the Colombian Caribbean), while Tegua gen. nov. and Muscopilio gen. nov. (that exhibit interesting green colorations on the DS and free tergite s), are genera found mostly on trees and rocks covered with mosses. So, in terms of biodiversity knowledge of Leiosteninae, we are hopefully, on the tip of the iceberg.

Difficulties with González -Sponga works /material Manuel Ángel González -Sponga (abbreviated here as G -S) was a Venezuelan prolific arachnologist (described more than 500 taxa) (Foghin 2009). For the case of Leiosteninae, he described 26 of the 59 current species, in three works (Gonz ález-Sponga 1981, 1987, 1998 ). In some cases, his production offer s drawings and descriptions that allow to easily identifying those species . However , I detected some issues that deserve attention:

(1) G-S product ion seems to decrease in quality as time went on . For example, the penis drawings of 1981 work are much better than those of 1987 (e.g. Figs 8F- G, 11F -G). In other cases, the drawings are drastically simplified and /or exhibits confusing information (e.g. Fig. 17E, drawings of genitalia in 1998 work).

(2) G-S considered his penis drawings self -explanatory : (…) for the species just a descriptive diagnosis, and not a comparative diagnosis, is given, because of the information of the keys and drawings, particularly those corresponding to male genitalia, let separate easily (…) (González -Sponga 1987: 12) . In fact, for all the species he didn’t describe the penis and just wrote: (…) Male genitalia: figures xxx and yyy (…).

(3) In a lot of species drawings, the genitalia shows “odd” macrosetae, i.e., macrosetae located in unusual places , as on the lateral projections of t he LP (see the genital ia of Ocoita mina in Fig. 17E ). In other cases, the stylus exhibits curious basal expansions (e.g. Ocoita species) or shapes quite different from those of the original description (e.g. original drawings of Balrog checkeleyi comb. nov . (Rambla, 1978) are very different from those offered by G-S).

Additionally , it is important to note that the private collection of G-S (acronym MAGS) remained unexplored until some time ago , when his family decided to donate it , before his dead in 2009 , to MIZA collection . In February of 2017 , I visited it and revised some of the material used (or not) in G -S descriptions . Unfortunately, additional information regarding the exomorphology and male genitalia of the species/genera was not recovered, becaus e of:

(1) The harvestmen of G -S collection were preserved in glass pots just with a collection number . The collecting data are maintained in bibliographical cards where the numbe r must be search ed to know the pro cedence of the material. (2) Some glass pots where in poor conditions (e.g. without alcohol, broken lids) and, because of that, dried or with fungus .

(3) The male genitalia were not preserved together with its corresponding exemplar. Each penis was preserved in a mini glass bottle (1 -2 ml) with a number tied to the bottle ´s neck , but all those bottles were stored together in a unique gl ass jar. When the large glass jar was examined, a lot of numbers were scattered in the bottom and, in consequence, a lot of m ini bottles were without number, b eing impossible to know the correspondence between collection number - male genitalia.

Besides that, some unlabeled topotypic material from Venezuela that was donated to the Museu Nacional plus the Leiosteninae material from at least 30 collections around the world that was loaned to us, was lost in the fire of 2018 (Kury et al. 2018). So, all these factors together with the current low representation of the Agoristenidae in the arachnology collections let us to infer that the only option to ascertain and c orroborate some aspects of the taxonomy and systematics of the Leiosteninae is to collect fresh material from the type localities.

CONCLUSION S  The genera Sabanilla and Andrescava are transferred to Globibuninae, and the latter is considered as a junior synonym of Globibunus . The species Avima scabra , Avima octomaculata and Avima olmosa are transferred to Globibuninae incertae sedis .

 Avima is no more considered as the collage of sp ecies of Leiosteninae. After its redescri ption and re definition, 25 new combinations are proposed and the genus is restricted to four species: A. leiobuniformis , A. intermedia , A. venezuelica and A. leucobunus .
 The penial setation and morphology is an inte resting tool for the systematics and taxonomy of the Leiosteninae, having in count that the exomorphology of several genera is very similar.

 A wider analysis, including more members of Agoristeninae and the genital information of Sabanilla and the three s pecies of “ Avima ” transferred to Globibuninae , can reveal new subfamilial and familial characters that can be used for further studies.

 Leiosteninae, that until now contained 12 genera and 59 species, now is represented by 18 genera (eight new) and 52 species (four new) (spp. in parenthesis): Avima (4), Balrog gen. nov. (6), Barinas (3), Barlovento (5), Eyabida gen. nov. (1), Jaibana gen. nov. (2), Leptostygnus (3), Lionza gen. nov. (2), Tegua gen. nov. (1), Muscopilio gen. nov. (1), Nemastygnus (2), Ocoita (2), Otrera gen. nov. (3), Paravima (9), Pantariste gen. nov. (3), Soroche gen. nov. (5), Taulisa (1) and Vima (2).
